author: Alexander the Great
author_funny_facts: Alexander the Great once visited Diogenes, a famous Greek philosopher. Diogenes was lying in the sun, and Alexander asked if there was anything he could do for him. Diogenes replied, 'Yes, stand out of my sunlight.'
Alexander the Great was known for his love of wine. He once drank a cup of unmixed wine before a battle to show his soldiers that he was not afraid of death.
Alexander the Great was so confident in his abilities as a military commander that he claimed to be the son of Zeus, the king of the gods.
author_interesting_facts: Alexander the Great's father, Philip II of Macedon, hired Aristotle to be Alexander's personal tutor. Aristotle taught Alexander philosophy, poetry, and politics.
Alexander the Great's conquests extended from Greece to India. He founded over 70 cities and named many after himself, including Alexandria in Egypt.
Alexander the Great died at the age of 32, possibly from malaria or poisoning. His empire was divided among his generals, leading to the Hellenistic period of ancient Greek history.
author_inspiring_facts: Alexander the Great was a skilled military commander who led his troops to victory in numerous battles. He inspired his soldiers with his bravery and determination.
Alexander the Great believed in leading by example. He fought alongside his soldiers in battle and shared their hardships.
Alexander the Great was a visionary leader who sought to unite the world under a single empire. His legacy as a conqueror and statesman continues to inspire people today.

author: Homer
author_description: c. 8th century BCE, legendary author of the Iliad and the Odyssey
author_funny_facts: Homer was said to be blind, but some scholars believe he may have been able to see.

In ancient Greece, it was believed that Homer was the son of a river god and a nymph.
author_interesting_facts: The Iliad and the Odyssey are considered two of the greatest works of Western literature.
The Trojan War, which is the subject of the Iliad, is thought to have taken place around 1200 BCE.
The Odyssey tells the story of Odysseus' journey home after the Trojan War.
author_inspiring_facts: Homer's epic poems have inspired countless works of literature, art, and music.
The Iliad and the Odyssey explore themes such as heroism, love, and the human condition.
Homer's works have been translated into numerous languages and continue to be studied and admired today.

Augustus was once gifted a very large and very old fish which had been caught in the Nile. He had it pickled and sent to Rome, where it was displayed as a curiosity.
Augustus loved to collect unusual and exotic animals, including a giraffe which was exhibited in Rome.
author_interesting_facts: Augustus was born Gaius Octavius, and was adopted by his great-uncle Julius Caesar in his will.
Augustus was the first emperor of Rome, and his reign marked the beginning of the Pax Romana, a period of relative peace and stability throughout the empire.
Augustus was a patron of the arts, and helped to promote the development of Roman literature and culture.
author_inspiring_facts: Augustus was known for his ability to unite and govern diverse peoples, and his leadership helped to establish the Roman Empire as a major world power.
Augustus was a strong advocate of civic virtue and moral behavior, and encouraged his subjects to follow the same principles.
Augustus was a skilled military strategist, and his victories in battle helped to expand the Roman Empire and secure its borders.

author: Queen Elizabeth II
author_description: 1926 - present, Queen of the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth realms

author_inspiring_facts: During World War II, the Queen trained as a mechanic and driver in the Women's Auxiliary Territorial Service.
She has made over 270 official overseas visits to 116 different countries.

author_description: 354 AD - 430 AD, Early Christian theologian and philosopher
author_funny_facts: Augustine was known for his love of food and once prayed, "Grant me chastity and continence, but not yet."

author_interesting_facts: Augustine wrote over 100 works during his lifetime, including 'The City of God' and 'Confessions'.

author: Antonio Vivaldi
author_funny_facts: Vivaldi was nicknamed 'il prete rosso' or 'the red priest' due to his red hair and being a Catholic priest.
It is rumored that Vivaldi wrote over 500 concertos in his lifetime, but only 230 have survived.

Vivaldi was once asked by a patron to compose a piece of music that imitated the sound of a thunderstorm. He responded with 'La Tempesta di Mare' or 'The Storm at Sea' which is now considered one of his most famous works.
author_interesting_facts: Vivaldi was a master of the violin and is credited with popularizing the instrument during the Baroque era.
Vivaldi spent much of his career as the music director at a girls' orphanage in Venice, where he composed most of his music.
Vivaldi's most famous work is 'The Four Seasons', a set of four violin concertos that depict the changing seasons of the year.
author_inspiring_facts: Vivaldi's music has been known to have a therapeutic effect on people with dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
Vivaldi's music has been used in numerous films and TV shows, including 'A Clockwork Orange', 'The Grand Budapest Hotel', and 'Master of None'.
Vivaldi's music continues to inspire and influence musicians today, over 250 years after his death.

Freud believed that human behavior is largely determined by our unconscious mind and childhood experiences.

author_funny_facts: Catherine the Great was known for her wit and humor. She once joked that she was 'an acquired taste, like caviar.'

author_interesting_facts: Catherine the Great was born in Germany as Princess Sophie of Anhalt-Zerbst and married into the Russian royal family.
She was a patron of the arts and founded the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg.
Catherine the Great was a strong ruler and expanded the Russian Empire through military conquest and diplomatic alliances.
author_inspiring_facts: Catherine the Great was a strong advocate for education and created schools for girls and boys throughout Russia.
She was also a proponent of religious tolerance and allowed people of different faiths to practice their religion freely.
Catherine the Great was a trailblazing female leader in a time when women were not often allowed to rule, and her legacy continues to inspire women around the world.

author: Ernest Rutherford
author_funny_facts: Rutherford once said, 'All science is either physics or stamp collecting.'
When asked what it felt like to discover the atom, Rutherford replied, 'It was as if you fired a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it came back and hit you.'
author_interesting_facts: Rutherford is known as the father of nuclear physics.
He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1908 for his work on radioactive decay.
Rutherford was the first person to split the atom, which led to the development of nuclear power and atomic bombs.
author_inspiring_facts: Rutherford believed in the importance of pure scientific research, saying, 'Research is to see what everybody else has seen, and to think what nobody else has thought.'

author: James Madison
author_description: 1751-1836, American statesman, diplomat, and philosopher who served as the fourth president of the United States
author_funny_facts: Madison was only 5 feet 4 inches tall, making him the shortest president in US history.

author_interesting_facts: Madison was one of the primary authors of the US Constitution and the Bill of Rights.
He played a pivotal role in the Louisiana Purchase, which doubled the size of the United States.
Madison was the last founding father to die, passing away in 1836 at the age of 85.
author_inspiring_facts: Madison believed in the importance of individual liberty and the protection of minority rights.
He was a strong advocate for religious freedom and believed in the separation of church and state.

author: Alexander Fleming
author_description: 1881-1955, Scottish biologist and pharmacologist who discovered penicillin
author_funny_facts: Fleming was known for being absent-minded and once left a petri dish of Staphylococcus bacteria uncovered on his laboratory bench. The bacteria was contaminated by a mold that had floated in through an open window, which led to the discovery of penicillin.

Fleming's mother was a famous embroiderer who created the altar cloth for Westminster Abbey's coronation of King George V in 1911. However, when Fleming was knighted in 1944, his mother declined an invitation to the ceremony because she was too busy with her embroidery.
Fleming's original penicillin mold was accidentally thrown away by a laboratory assistant and had to be rediscovered from a contaminated culture.
author_interesting_facts: Fleming was a member of the London Scottish Regiment during World War I and was awarded the Military Cross for his bravery on the front lines.
Apart from his work on penicillin, Fleming also researched on lysozyme, a natural antibacterial enzyme found in tears, egg whites, and other bodily fluids.
Fleming was a member of the Royal Society and was awarded numerous honors throughout his career, including the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1945.
author_inspiring_facts: Fleming's discovery of penicillin revolutionized medicine and is credited with saving millions of lives from bacterial infections.
Despite being initially dismissed by the medical community, Fleming persisted in his research and ultimately proved the effectiveness of penicillin.
Fleming believed in the importance of collaboration and credited his discovery of penicillin to the contributions of his colleagues and the accidental contamination of his bacteria culture.

author_funny_facts: Andersen was afraid of being buried alive, so he carried a note with him at all times that read, “I only appear to be dead.”

Andersen was known to talk to himself and his objects of inspiration, including his shoes and his inkwell.
author_interesting_facts: Andersen's most famous works include The Little Mermaid, Thumbelina, and The Ugly Duckling.
He was born into poverty and had very little formal education, but he taught himself to read and write.
Andersen was a prolific traveler and visited many countries in Europe, as well as Egypt and Turkey.
author_inspiring_facts: Despite facing many personal and professional challenges, Andersen never gave up on his dream of becoming a writer.
He was known for his dedication to his craft, often working 14-16 hours a day to perfect his stories.

author_funny_facts: Orwell originally wanted to name his famous book 1984 as The Last Man in Europe.
George Orwell’s real name was Eric Arthur Blair.
Orwell was known to have kept a goat by the name of Muriel.
author_interesting_facts: Orwell’s novel Animal Farm, published in 1945, was written as a satire of the Soviet Union and the rise of Stalin.
Orwell fought in the Spanish Civil War and was almost killed by a sniper.
Orwell’s thought-provoking essay, Politics and the English Language, is still widely read today and is often used as a guide for good writing.
author_inspiring_facts: Orwell’s work has inspired countless writers and thinkers. His novels and essays continue to be studied in schools and universities around the world.
Orwell was a passionate advocate for social justice and equality. His writing often tackled issues of poverty, inequality, and oppression.
Orwell’s commitment to truth and honesty has made him an inspiration to journalists and writers everywhere.

author: Rudolph Virchow
author_description: 1821-1902, German physician, anthropologist, pathologist, prehistorian, biologist and politician
author_funny_facts: Virchow was once refused entry to a medical conference because he was considered too young to be a doctor.
He was once asked why he had not performed an autopsy on a particular patient, to which he replied, "I couldn't get the patient to agree to it."
Virchow was known for his sarcasm and wit, and was once quoted as saying, "Medicine is a social science, and politics is nothing else but medicine on a large scale."
author_interesting_facts: Virchow was one of the first scientists to study the effects of disease on different parts of the body.
He is often referred to as the "Father of Modern Pathology".
Virchow was a pioneer in the field of public health, and was instrumental in establishing the first public health system in Germany.
author_inspiring_facts: Virchow believed that medicine was not just about treating individual patients, but also about improving the health of entire populations.
He was a strong advocate for social justice, and believed that poverty and inequality were the root causes of many diseases.
Virchow's work helped lay the foundation for modern epidemiology, and his ideas continue to influence public health policy today.

author: Cyrus the Great
author_description: c. 600 BC – 530 BC, founder of the Achaemenid Empire
author_funny_facts: Cyrus was known for his love of wine and parties.

Cyrus was said to have had a pet lion that he treated like a house cat.
author_interesting_facts: Cyrus was the first Persian king to conquer Babylon.
He was known for his religious tolerance and allowed the Jews to return to their homeland after being exiled in Babylon.
Cyrus was a skilled military strategist and was able to conquer much of the known world at the time.
author_inspiring_facts: Cyrus was a benevolent ruler who was loved by his people.

Cyrus's legacy as a great ruler and pioneer of human rights is still celebrated today.

author: Dante Alighieri
author_funny_facts: Dante was once exiled from his hometown of Florence and was sentenced to death by burning if he returned.
Dante's most famous work, The Divine Comedy, was written in the Tuscan dialect instead of the more prestigious Latin, making it accessible to a wider audience.
Dante's tomb was lost for centuries until it was rediscovered in 1865 during an excavation in Ravenna.
author_interesting_facts: Dante wrote The Divine Comedy in three parts, each representing a different afterlife realm: Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven.
The Divine Comedy has been translated into over 100 languages and is considered one of the greatest works of world literature.
Dante's political beliefs were a major influence on his writing, and he was a strong supporter of a united Italy.
author_inspiring_facts: Dante's work has inspired countless artists, writers, and thinkers throughout history.
Dante's focus on individual responsibility and moral accountability has made his work relevant to contemporary discussions on ethics and morality.

author: Francis Bacon
author_description: 1561-1626, English philosopher, statesman, scientist, jurist, and author
author_funny_facts: Bacon is credited with the development of the scientific method, but he once caught a cold experimenting with snow
Bacon was once sued by a man who claimed he had been injured after Bacon’s carriage hit him
Bacon believed that people should not blindly follow authority, but he himself was a loyal servant of the British Crown
author_interesting_facts: Bacon was the youngest son of Sir Nicholas Bacon, who was Lord Keeper of the Great Seal under Queen Elizabeth I
Bacon was imprisoned in the Tower of London for a brief period on charges of bribery
Bacon's works include essays, philosophical and scientific treatises, and a history of the reign of King Henry VII
author_inspiring_facts: Bacon's philosophy emphasized the importance of empirical evidence and observation in scientific inquiry
Bacon believed that knowledge is power and that education is the key to unlocking human potential
Bacon's ideas on the separation of powers and the rule of law were influential in the development of modern democracies

author: Guglielmo Marconi
author_description: 1874-1937, Italian inventor and electrical engineer, credited with developing the first practical radio communication system
author_funny_facts: Marconi's mother was Irish and his father was Italian, so he was able to speak both languages fluently. However, he often mixed up the two, resulting in some hilarious misunderstandings.
Marconi was known for being a bit absent-minded. Once, he forgot to attend his own wedding rehearsal, causing quite a stir among his family and friends.
Despite his many achievements, Marconi was never able to invent a device that would allow him to be in two places at once.
author_interesting_facts: Marconi was only 20 years old when he began his experiments with radio communication.
In 1909, Marconi shared the Nobel Prize in Physics with Karl Ferdinand Braun for their contributions to the development of wireless telegraphy.
During World War I, Marconi worked on developing wireless communication systems for the military, which helped to greatly improve communication between troops and their commanders.
author_inspiring_facts: Marconi's work on wireless communication revolutionized the way people communicate over long distances, paving the way for modern technologies like cell phones and the internet.
Marconi was a true pioneer in the field of electrical engineering, and his dedication to his work helped to change the world in countless ways.
Despite facing many challenges and setbacks throughout his career, Marconi never gave up on his dream of developing practical wireless communication systems.

author: Hippocrates
author_description: 460 BC - 370 BC, Greek physician considered as the father of modern medicine
author_funny_facts: Hippocrates is believed to have written over 70 books, but only a few of them survived the test of time
He is known to have said 'Walking is man's best medicine', but he probably never had a dog
It is said that Hippocrates was a fan of the game 'Knucklebones', which was similar to modern-day Jacks
author_interesting_facts: Hippocrates believed that the human body has the innate ability to heal itself, and it is the job of the physician to facilitate this process
He wrote extensively on topics such as diet, exercise, and mental health, long before these became popular fields of study
Hippocrates is credited with creating the Hippocratic Oath, a code of ethics for physicians that is still used today
author_inspiring_facts: Hippocrates believed in treating the patient as a whole, not just the symptoms, which is now known as the holistic approach to medicine
His emphasis on prevention and maintaining good health through a healthy lifestyle is still relevant today
Hippocrates is a reminder that even in ancient times, there were individuals who were passionate about improving the lives of others through medicine and healing

author_funny_facts: Tolkien was once asked to speak Elvish to a Swedish couple who had asked for directions in Oxford. He obliged, and was rewarded with a surprised and delighted look from the couple.
Tolkien was known for correcting people who mispronounced words, and would often interrupt conversations to do so.
Tolkien disliked the Beatles, and once referred to them as 'a pimple' on the face of music.

author: Nikola Tesla
author_description: 1856-1943, Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, and futurist who is best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system.
author_funny_facts: Nikola Tesla had a photographic memory and spoke eight languages, but had a peculiar obsession with the number 3.

author_interesting_facts: Tesla had over 300 patents worldwide and was known for his work on the Tesla coil and the AC motor.

Tesla was fascinated with wireless communication and attempted to create a global communication system called the Wardenclyffe Tower.
author_inspiring_facts: Tesla believed in the power of renewable energy and wanted to harness the energy of the Earth's magnetic field to provide free electricity to everyone.

author: Paul the Apostle
author_description: 5 - 67 AD, Christian missionary and writer of the New Testament
author_funny_facts: Paul was once bitten by a poisonous snake, but he miraculously survived.
Paul was a tentmaker by trade and continued to make tents even after he became an apostle.
Paul's Roman citizenship allowed him to avoid being flogged or beaten with rods.
author_interesting_facts: Paul was originally named Saul and was a persecutor of Christians before his conversion.
Paul wrote 13 of the 27 books in the New Testament.
Paul was imprisoned multiple times for his teachings and was eventually executed in Rome.

author: Ptolemy
author_description: AD 90 - AD 168, Greco-Roman mathematician, astronomer, geographer, and astrologer
author_funny_facts: Ptolemy's model of the universe was so complex that it required over 80 epicycles to predict the motion of the planets.
Ptolemy believed that the Earth was at the center of the universe, which was a common belief at the time.
Ptolemy's work was so influential that his theories were accepted for over 1,000 years, despite their inaccuracies.
author_interesting_facts: Ptolemy's most famous work is the Almagest, which was a comprehensive study of astronomy that included a star catalogue with over 1,000 stars.
Ptolemy's work on geography was also groundbreaking, as he created the first world map with lines of longitude and latitude.
Ptolemy's theories on optics influenced the development of the telescope and the study of optics for centuries.
author_inspiring_facts: Ptolemy's dedication to the study of astronomy and geography paved the way for future scientific advancements.
Ptolemy's work on the Almagest inspired many astronomers and astrologers to continue studying the stars and planets.
Ptolemy's theories on optics and the nature of light were instrumental in the development of modern physics and the study of light.
